ud5.6:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Savatthi in Jeta’s Grove, Anathapindika’s monastery.
ud5.6:1.3: Now at that time Venerable Mahakaccana was staying in the land of the Avantis near Kuraraghara on Steep Mountain.
ud5.6:1.4: And the layman Sona of the Sharp Ears was Mahakaccana’s attendant.
ud5.6:2.1: Then as Sona was in private retreat this thought came to his mind,
ud5.6:2.2: “As I understand Master Mahakaccana’s teachings, it’s not easy for someone living at home to lead the spiritual life utterly full and pure, like a polished shell.
ud5.6:2.3: Why don’t I shave off my hair and beard, dress in ocher robes, and go forth from lay life to homelessness?”
ud5.6:3.1: Then Sona went up to Mahakaccana, bowed, sat down to one side, and told him what he was thinking. Then he said,
ud5.6:4.4: “May Master Mahakaccana please give me the going forth!”
ud5.6:5.1: When this was said, Mahakaccana said to him,
ud5.6:5.2: “It’s hard to lead the spiritual life as long as you live, eating in one part of the day and sleeping alone.
ud5.6:5.3: Come now, Sona, while remaining a layperson just as you are, devote yourself to the instructions of the Buddhas, leading the spiritual life at suitable times, eating in one part of the day and sleeping alone.”
ud5.6:5.4: Then Sona’s aspiration to go forth died down.
ud5.6:6.1: For a second time, while in private retreat the thought came to Sona that he should go forth, but the outcome was the same.
ud5.6:7.1: For a third time, as Sona was in private retreat this thought came to his mind,
ud5.6:7.2: “As I understand Master Mahakaccana’s teachings, it’s not easy for someone living at home to lead the spiritual life utterly full and pure, like a polished shell.
ud5.6:7.3: Why don’t I shave off my hair and beard, dress in ocher robes, and go forth from lay life to homelessness?”
ud5.6:7.4: For a third time, Sona went up to Mahakaccana, bowed, sat down to one side, and told him what he was thinking. Then he said,
ud5.6:8.4: “May Master Mahakaccana please give me the going forth!”
ud5.6:9.1: Then Mahakaccana gave Sona the going forth.
ud5.6:9.2: Now at that time the southern region, including Avanti, was short of monks.
ud5.6:9.3: It took three years and much struggle and difficulty before Venerable Mahakaccayana was able to assemble from here and there a Sangha consisting of ten monks and give Venerable Sona the full ordination.
ud5.6:10.1: Then as Venerable Sona was in private retreat this thought came to his mind,
ud5.6:10.2: “I have not personally seen the Buddha. I have only heard reports that
ud5.6:10.3: that Blessed One is like this or like that.
ud5.6:10.4: If my mentor allows, I should go to see that Blessed One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha.”
ud5.6:11.1: Then in the late afternoon, Sona came out of retreat, went up to Mahakaccana, bowed, sat down to one side, and told him what he was thinking. Then Mahakaccana said,
ud5.6:13.2: Go to see the Blessed One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha.
ud5.6:13.3: You will see that Blessed One who is impressive and inspiring, with peaceful faculties and mind, attained to the highest self-control and serenity, like an elephant with tamed, guarded, and controlled faculties.
ud5.6:13.4: On seeing him, in my name bow with your head to his feet. Ask him if he is healthy and well, nimble, strong, and living comfortably, saying,
ud5.6:13.5: ‘Sir, my mentor Venerable Mahakaccana bows with his head to your feet. He asks if you are healthy and well, nimble, strong, and living comfortably.’”
ud5.6:14.1: Saying, “Yes, sir,” Sona welcomed and agreed with Mahakaccana’s words. He got up from his seat, bowed, and respectfully circled Mahakaccana, keeping him on his right. Then he set his lodgings in order and, taking his bowl and robe, set out for Savatthi.
ud5.6:14.2: Eventually he came to Savatthi and Jeta’s Grove. He went up to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down to one side.
ud5.6:14.4: “Sir, my mentor Venerable Mahakaccana bows with his head to your feet. He asks if you are healthy and well, nimble, strong, and living comfortably.”
ud5.6:15.1: “I hope you’re keeping well, mendicant; I hope you’re all right. And I hope you have arrived from your journey unwearied, having had no trouble getting almsfood.”
ud5.6:15.2: “I’m keeping well, Blessed One; I’m all right. And I have arrived from my journey unwearied, having had no trouble getting almsfood.”
ud5.6:16.1: Then the Buddha said to Venerable Ananda,
ud5.6:16.5: to prepare lodgings for a specific mendicant, he wishes to stay in the same dwelling with that mendicant. The Buddha wishes to stay together with Venerable Sona.”
ud5.6:16.6: He prepared lodgings for Sona in the same dwelling where the Buddha was staying.
ud5.6:17.1: The Buddha spent much of the night sitting meditation in the open. Then he got up from his seat, washed his feet and entered the dwelling.
ud5.6:17.3: Then the Buddha rose at the crack of dawn and addressed Sona,
ud5.6:17.4: “Speak some Dhamma, mendicant, as you feel inspired.”
ud5.6:18.1: “Yes, sir,” replied Sona. He intoned all sixteen discourses in the Chapter of the Eights.
ud5.6:18.2: When Sona finished his intoning, the Buddha applauded, saying,
ud5.6:18.3: “Good, good, mendicant! You have learned the sixteen discourses of the Chapter of the Eights well, you have applied the mind and remembered it well. You are a good speaker, with a polished, clear, and articulate voice that expresses the meaning.
ud5.6:18.4: How many rains have you been ordained, mendicant?”
ud5.6:18.6: “But why did it take you so long to make it?”
ud5.6:18.7: “Sir, I have long seen the drawbacks of sensual pleasures,
ud5.6:18.8: yet living in a house is cramped, with many duties and much to do.”
ud5.6:19.1: Then, understanding this matter, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:
ud5.6:20.2: I understood the truth without attachments.
ud5.6:20.3: The Noble One does not delight in evil,
ud5.6:20.4: the Pure One does not delight in evil.”
